2.

Reeds have a family of seven boys all under 11 years of age,- an interesting family,
On Thursday I had a funeral of one of our ladies who had been in poor health for a number of years, we buried her 14 or 15 miles distant. So I spent all day in making the round, Helen did not go, as she is not very strong for such long drives, 
Week after week our local (Northwestern) Association meets at Stockton about fifty miles South West, and a very hard to be reached from here as the railroad conventions are very poor, we will, some of us, probably manage to drive over the whole or a part of the way.
The children are at work in the

3.
school, Roberts still working also in the depot, mornings before school, afternoons after school, and Saturdays. He also has to be there Sundays about an hour or two in the morning.
Our congregations are coming out pretty well after the vacation,- better than I had heard they might. A young lady who has been our organist for year or more goes next week to Northwestern University-, at Evanston, Ill to take music and other things. The choir met Thursday night, and presented her with about 13 or 14 dollars, They had intended getting some thing for her but she seemed to possess almost everything

(4

that a girl could be expected to care for; so they gave her the cash.
Write when you can,
In some haste
With much love
Your Nephew
J.E.Everett

Smith Center, Kansas, 
Sept 21, 1908
My Dear Aunt Mary:
For a week or more I have neglected writing you. It seems sometimes that my regular work takes about all the time I have. Last week I was pretty busy though I did not seem to accomplish much. Next week I go to attend the meeting of our local congregational association at Almena sixty miles or so west of here. It is the Northwestern Assn. I have a paper to preface which will take some of my time this week. Indeed two papers - one of which should be quite short however, but which will take perhaps as much

time as the other.
We were glad Saturday to receive your good long letter.
Helen is possibly being threatened with some sort of fever. In all event, she feels much as she did once in did once in fever when the doctor thought she was coming down with typhoid. She is just able to be about, but we hope it will not become more serious. 
Zaidee has just had a run of tonsillitis. Her throat broke Saturday afternoon. She did not have to be out of school at all though it was hard for her for a few days.
Thursday and Friday afternoons there was no school, on account of our County fair being in progress. That was a help to her.

3.
The rest of us are well. Edward seems to enjoy his school. He has already showed the signs of change that are generally seen when children begin to go to school. He is not nearly so timid as before. He would hardly go a block away alone for fear of dogs and other monsters. But now he goes to school and back, four blocks away, and has no fear whatever, and he comes home alone & sometimes goes alone. His mother thinks he talks a little more plainly.
Robert has insisted on putting on long pantaloons, so we him a pair after getting home. Now we must get him a suit because he has no coat suitable to go with the long pants.
Howard told us in a recent letter

of having written you, and you mentioned in your last. I am glad he did not neglect doing so. He is like the rest of us in that matter I fear. Though he writes home very faithfully and regularly, scarcely missing a week.
We have had hot day weather here since our return.
A week ago last Saturday - that is a week ago last night - I read a paper before my church on our Eastern trip. If I can get the time to copy it off I will send you a copy. It is not in very readable shape as it is, as I have interlined some.
I suppose it would be more care than you should assume to have Margaret with you for the Winter.

5.
though I am sure you would take good care of her and that she would enjoy being with you. She seems to enjoy her school. She does not take very kindly to arithmetic, but does well in other things. She likes to read story books chiefly. We have had to discourage this lately because of her eyes. She has headaches daily sometimes, and we are not sure but it is from her eyes: - indeed we think it is.
She got into "Little Women" lately, and it is a pretty long book, but it is two parts and we finally prevailed on her to give it up for the present at the end of the first part.
Margaret says she thinks the school

6.
doors all open outwards.
Helen means to write you, but she has been so poorly, and busy that she seems to have no time. She has had to rest quite a good deal.
Helen thinks she has one of your napkins and we will send it.
I will now close 
With a great deal of love,
Your nephew,
J.E. Everett

Smith Center, Kansas
Nov. 16, 1908
My Dear Aunt Mary: - 
Another communication came this morning from Cousin Fannie, saying that you were at the time of writing doing nicely. That was Friday, the day after your arm was set. I hope you continue thus. I think you are likely to get along well under the good care that I am sure you are having. Indeed, I almost believe you will find your hospital experience rather

enjoyable, as you can, I suppose, use your time a good deal as you like, visiting at times with others there, and retiring to be by yourself when you choose to do so. Do you have any idea how long you will be there? I suspect the healing process will be somewhat slow. Do you have a great deal of pain?
I wish we were near enough to drop in occasionally to see you. But I am glad that the case is not so bad as to call us to visit whether far or near.
We had two quite good and novel services yesterday, as the programs I sent you Saturday indicated. In the

morning, we had a peoples meeting, with five our members taking part with papers & address. The ladies, four of them, had their ideas written down & they read their papers. The man, Mr. Makin spoke offhand. The meeting was good and interesting. Our people's meetings hitherto have been addressed by men entirely: - with one exception, however, when two young ladies took part. We were glad to get the ladies to take part yesterday. 
In the evening Judge Pickles gave a good address on the poetry of the Bible.
We are also each week, lately, making especial effort with our en-

deavor service. We had a good meeting last night, with the program that you see on the folder.
We feel that our work is keeping along pretty hopefully. Our congregations are not so large as for some time after the great revival, but for the most part they are keeping up pretty well.
We usually have a pretty good attendance and an attentive hearing.
With a great deal of love,
Your nephew,
J.E. Everett

Smith Center, Kansas
Feb 27, 1910
My Dear Aunt Mary:
Your letter of the 22nd, with additions later has just come. We had a great storm here on Sunday last, the 25th. It snowed from early in the morning I think, and continued all day, to perhaps late into the night. It blew very hard also. It was a regular New York storm. I do not remember seeing its like in Kansas.There were deep drifts all about and I had a good deal of shoveling on Monday. The trains were blockaded and have not got to running regularly yet. This (Tuesday) afternoon we got the first mail from the East, except a small amount that came last night. Your letter came in the belated lot this after-

-noon. Our storm was not a cold one, the thermometer not going below 20° above, I suppose, till after the storm subsided. It seems that about a foot of snow on the level fell. Our rural mail carriers have not been out yesterday or today.
The house that David Griffith has bought must be the John Ty Log house. I rememember when it was built. Mr. Jones came to see Uncle Lewis' house, and modeled the new house after that. That is my recollection of it at all events. I was just a small boy. I remember when John Ty Log was baptized. He was an old man then, or at least he seemed to be such to me, though I think he lived a number of years after that. It was in the spring of 1879. He

was immersed by Rev. Mr. Babcock, a pastor at that time of the M.E. Church in Remsen. The immersion was in the creek in the village.
I am sorry to learn that Emma Davis has been poorly. I vividly remember when she and I were playmates in the Fuller's school; and also when Henry and I were in the Remsen school together under Horace O. Farley.  I think the teacher in our district when Emma and I went there together was Jennie Owens. Both she and Mr. Farley have now passed from earth. 
I received a nice letter from Cousin Fannie a short time ago. I had sent her a picture of Robert at

4.
Christmas and her letter was in response to that. In reply I wrote a letter to her mother as I was told that she likes to get letters though she does not write much now.
Roberts' eyes finally got quite bad, and he went to a good physician in Oberlin who, after examination, refused to do anything saying that a specialist must be consulted. He (as nearly as I remember Roberts' report to us) said that there was nervous freakishness, astygmatism, and a little pyramid shaped piece entirely missing from one of the pupils. Roberts made an appointment with the specialist

5.
recommended in Cleveland, Dr Landers (or Lauders - I am not sure whether is a u or an n) The last letter we received told of his meeting the appointment and getting glasses. It was a week ago Saturday that he went; and his examination was at 10 o'clock that morning when drops were put into his eyes. He suffered a severe headache afterwards till the next evening when he wrote us. The glasses he got also hurt his eyes badly, but he hoped that he would get adjusted to them. He is to go back to Cleveland every two weeks for a time.

(6

We have heard nothing from him since then, but think we will surely hear in a day or two, as we have been hearing all the time at least once a week & quite often twice. We feel badly about the eye trouble; but hope that when the glasses are finally properly adjusted he will be able to go along with his studies without being seriously hampered. 
Our meetings were very fine and in some ways quite satisfactory. There were not many accessions resulting, but the meetings did the church good. The preacher, Dr. H. A. Tucker of Fort Scott, is a man of fine

(7

spirit whom all admired. We had bad weather during about half the time the meetings were in progress, which we thought was a hindrance. We will receive in all about 12 into membership, and quite largely this is a result of the meetings, though I think not entirely six of these are under 14 years of age, one only about 8. Two are a young man & his wife, he making a profession of religion for the first time now, + she coming by letter from our ME Church here. They join us partly

(8

because it his choice & partly because she has not felt quite at home in the M.E. Church.
I must now close. I hope this will find you as well as you were when you wrote the letter we have just received. 
Write when you can. We are always very glad to get your letters.
When your letter comes in the mail, it seems different from other envelopes that come in the mailbox.
With much love as ever
Your Nephew
J.E. Everett

Smith Center Kansas
January 19, 1912
My Dear Aunt Mary:
We were very glad to receive your letter yesterday morning, but sorry to know that you had been worrying about us during the recent cold weather. The old settlers say that there had not been such cold weather continuously for so long a time before; but then I think that people forget just what the past seasons were. However our weather station at Topeka declared our cold spell to be he severest on record; but I suppose it was pretty bad. We did not suffer, as we had plenty of coal in the coal house; and a plenty in town if we had needed it. I thought that if the extreme cold should continued until February, our coal would be exhausted

(2

then came threats of a coal famine here; so we got some extra coal, and now have enough to last late in the spring if not all that we will need until warm weather. In some parts of the state West and South West, there was suffering, both of people and stock.
We have had snow on the ground since December 20. It has been thawing a little in the sun for a day or two. One good Kansas day would make the snow go fast; and quite likely it may not be with us much longer, though two years ago we had snow from November until about March 1st, a very unusual thing.
I was glad to receive the letter you enclosed from Cousin Jennie.
I believe I wrote you of intending to go to Stockton the first of January to help with meetings there. On account of the cold weather the meetings were deferred, so I have been at home. We are expecting

(3

to begin a series of evangelistic meetings in our church on the 4th of February. We are to be assisted by  Dr. H.A. Tucker, our pastor at present at Fort Scott, and one whom has been exclusively in evangelistic work for a number of years. 
The children have thus far been quite well this winter. One or two little colds have been in evidence; but nothing to be called serious or to give trouble. We keep Edward and Mary out of school a half day or day occasionally when we think they need the rest. Margaret seems well these days. For the past year she has been stronger than for several years previously. She is developing into a woman and we are glad to see her health apparently improved.
I hope Roberts is doing well. We have been hearing from him often. He seems to be getting interested in his work. I am glad he called a

(4

Dr. Jones. He did not mention it in his letter to us. I wish he had called on Dr. Cross; but quite likely he did not do so; as a young fellow like that feels a shrinking from calling on strangers. I would, at this age, have been quite unlikely to make such a call. He is working now in a hotel as water, and getting his board and room for about 4 hours work each day.
Later: A letter from Roberts has just come. He has been writing two or three times a week most of the time. He complained of his eyes troubling him in his last letter but says nothing in this, so I suppose they are better. He thought he would have to be fitted for glasses again, as the trouble seemed to be like his first trouble about 6 years ago. He has had no trouble for more than four years before & has not worn glasses in that time.

(5

It is time for me to get to work in my study and I must now close. I am very glad you are keeping so well this winter. I hope you may continue to be well for the rest of the season.
With a great deal of love
Your Nephew and Brother
J.E. Everett

1820 Clay Street
Topeka, Kan., Oct 13, 1906,
My Dear Aunt Mary: - 
I came home Wednesday, having heard the latter part of last week that Edward and Mary were quite sick. Edward had some breaking out on his face with swelling, and he also felt pretty badly in other ways. On returning home, I found them both pretty well again. Indeed, I had received a letter in the meantime, saying that they were better, but I had got my head set, by that time, in the direction of home, and so came anyway. I shall remain until about next Wednesday, when I expect to return for a short time, probably for not longer

than a week or two. I hoping to visit a church with a view to settling permanently, before very long, - probably not later than November 4.
I find that the children have grown some during the summer, and that they have improved.
Roberts is quite disappointed because he had to be put back a grade in his school, on account of the Topeka schools being graded to a higher standard than the Severy schools. But he is a half a year ahead of most of those who used to be in the same classes with him when we were in Topeka before. He would have been admitted into the high school here, as it is, with some conditions, but the superintendant said that he was too

very likely get the start of Edward in this respect.
Helen has just called my attention to a picture of Roberts taken when he was three years old - a picture in which he is leaning over the back of a chair, and we think it looks enough like Edward now to be his picture.
Helen tells me that she wrote you in a recent letter of our hopes that the Wellington church might open to us. We have been looking for this since last April. Our superintendent, Dr. Thayer, who not only has oversight of Home Missionary work, but acts as a sort of Bureau between ministers and churches, has had this in view, and the retiring pastor of Wellington has also suggested me to the church there, but it has not seemed wise for

3

young to do that. Margaret has also been put a grade behind where she thinks she belongs. She is getting now so that she can read simple books herself. She has now a library book from the city library which she is reading. She is a very sweet, fine little girl with good disposition. 
Edward does not talk plain yet. I can not understand only about a half of what he says. He is bright and active and will get around to his speech after awhile.
Little Mary is a very sweet, pretty girl. They tell me that she has cried pretty nearly all summer, but it has evidently not disagreed with her seriously for she is plump and healthy looking, and is developing in every way. She tried to talk, and we think she will

5

him to resign till recently. His resignation was accepted this week Wednesday; and we are now expecting an invitation for me to visit the church for a month as a candidate. I may not be asked to do this but rather expect it during the next few days. Then after that, it is of course uncertain whether anything further would come of it all. For some reasons, we would like to go there. There is a good high school there as well as good schools lower down. It is a town of some advantages, though the church is not counted among the foremost in the state, it ranks much better in some ways than any that we have yet had.
I ought to return to Fowler for the 21 and in all probability -

will do so. There are some members to be received into membership there, and that is the regular Congregational Sunday there.
Howard yesterday brought clippings from the Hutchinson papers telling of the marriage of Cousin Charlie. Carroll performed the ceremony, and Uncle Eddie and Aunt Mate? were there, but more of the rest of the family.
I must now close. I hope to hear from you again soon.
With a lot of lover
Your Nephew
J.E. Everett

My Dear Aunt Mary;

   I want to see you very much. I am lonesome for you.  Mary is awful naughty. Ogga was with papa down town and mailed  Mary's picture to you. We are all, all right. Mary has been getting up on a stool and and playing in the water. We have got a stove up. Ogga has been helping Mama clear off the table.   Roberts beats the rugs.   A man brought us Howard's trunk. Howard gave me some time table books. Mama is making some flour pancakes, Mama made some cake. Mama is making a coat for Margaret.  Zaidee wanted the Fuss Budget book, to read to her scholers. We

got a picture rack. That Fuss Budget book is good. Roberts has been reading it to us. Papa got me an A.B.C. book. Papa got Margaret a little bit of piggie. We got an old broken chair. Howard brought up two pretty Indian pictures. I shut Howard up in the closet, and Howard shut me up in the closet. I have to tell that Margaret is a good girl because she teased me to, Mary has been playing peek-a-boo with papa. Roberts fixed the old hammock. It's all broken now, and no good. I would like to see you.   Mama gave me that old, old clock.

     Your loving Nephew
               Edward Everett,

I wipe the dishes for mama sometimes.

Smith Center, Kansas
July 20, 1912
My Dear Aunt Mary: —
We received a letter from Robert this morning and he says that by the tone of a letter received from you, he is afraid you are going to write Mr. Sturges, showing your interes in what he is doing for Roberts. He hopes you have not done this and will not do so. He says Mr. S. is very sensitive on such matters, and Roberts feels that it would be better to have nothing more said to him. I have a good mind to enclose R's letter. It sounds pretty positive, & possibly a trifle blunt, but you will un-

-derstand he is writing with freedom to his parents. I believe I would say nothing to him of having heard from me about the matter. He too is averse to having his affairs discussed too much. I do not know but this is natural. A good many people are that way. I think I am myself.

  I rather suspect that R. may visit you after the close of the summer term which is about the middle of August.  The fall term does not begin till about Sept 20. If he gets work in N.Y. he will stay there; it not, he will probably go to you.
  I have had a nice letter from Prof. F.M. Burdick and one from Rev.

3.
Anthony Evans, in reply to my letter. Both are out of the city,- not to return till September. Prof. Burdick's son is in the city however. He is also on the law faculty of Columbia, & is teaching in the summer school there.
I have written to Roland Williams and his Cousin Josephine.
I have thought of Dr. Finch and Miss Ray. But it is so many years since I have seen or heard of them that hardly think it worth while to try to hunt them up. Dr. Finch would surely be quite advanced in years by this time. He seemed to me almost an old man 38

4
years ago, in 1874, when he examined me on the multiplication table to where to place me when I entered the 40th street school.
I would not send you Roberts' letter if I thought it would make you feel badly, But I am sure you will understand, - both how he might write such a letter us in the family, and also how he feels about the present situation.
We are about as usual. Our 7-day Chautauqua begins on the 4th a week from tomorrow.

5
I have a vacation through August. I will not go any where in particular & do not need a vacation, but our experience here convinces us that the church pulls to the work better in the fall if there is a few weeks cessation in the hot weather. So from my point of view the object this year is primarily to give the church a vacation, though it would not be gracious to put it so bluntly to our people, because they are of course kind to be willing to give me a good vacation ungrudgingly, each year.

(5 
home, he had let the matter slip. I think he will try to write when he gets to feeling settled in New York, & gets a little caught up in his work, as he was a few days late in entering. I will now close. We are as usual in health here. Edward is out in the country for a few days, rusticating. 
Write when you can 
With much Love 
Your Nephew 
JE Everett

(6
I shall be away for the most part, I think Sundays, - visiting. I think, some neighboring Congregational Churches. On the first Sunday I will, I suppose stay at home & attend the Chautauqua. 
Write when you can 
Very Affectionately 
Your Neph-Brother 
J. E. Everett

Smith Center, Kansas
July 18, 1913
My Dear Aunt Mary: -
Your letter of the 16th came today; also one from you to Helen that she sent me.
No, you do not need to help us out on this trip. We are going to get along all right. Thank you most heartily, however, for your generous offer.
Recent letters from Helen make it seem improbable that we can reach you till the week following the 3rd. Possibly we may not get there till Wednesday, the 6, though, I think it will be on the 5. I had no idea of being later than Saturday the 2nd

but Helen says I will have to stop at Will Glaziers a day or two, and a letter from him makes it rather evident that I must do so. So that will delay us till after Sunday.
I would very much like to have Roberts go to Wales to our ancestral spot; but as it would probably increase his expense I cannot urge him to do so. I very much wish however that it might fit into his plans.
I will not write more now
With Love
Your Nephew Brother
J.E. Everett

After 5 days, return to
OSAWATOMIE STATE BANK,
OSAWATOMIE, KANS.
OSAWATOMIE
OCT.
14
1130 AM
1902
KANS.
UNITED STATES POSTAGE
TWO 2 CENTS
J.E. Everett,
Topeka,
Kans.
703 Jackson St.

GENERAL OFFICE
The Kansas State Temperance Union.
703 JACKSON STREET, TOPEKA.
Make all money orders payable to "State Temperance Union."
Topeka, Kansas, Oct. 13, 1902.
Mr. O.T. Beeson, Cashier,
Osawatomie, Kansas.
My dear Sir: --
Our next installment of rent from the farm will not be paid until early in November, and I wish to have the privilege of deferring payment of the note until after this rent money is received. I had intended doing what little business I have at Osawatomie at your bank, but I rented the farm this year through an agent, who had the notes payable at the F. and M. Bank. I will attend to the note as soon as I learn of this money being paid.
I may say that my mistake in overdrawing my account was one of the results of renting the farm through an agent and not directly. The terms were somewhat different from those of preceding years, the first payment being in November instead of earlier in the year. I had no paid especial attention to that provision and had forgotten it and so presumed there was plenty of money in the bank. However, I think I am getting a better rent than if I had done the business myself.
Sincerely yours,
J..Ed. Everett.
P.S. Let me know, please, whether it will be all right for me to defer payment till the rent money is paid in November 3. J.E.E.
All right. Hope you can have the business transferred to us again. 
Yours truly
O.T. Beeson.

Hamilton College
Clinton N.Y. Dec 11, '85
My Dear Ones at Home: -
I have neglected writing to you more than you have to me lately. In another week I shall be at home I presume. Our examinations begun to-day. We have just had one in Tacitus History of the Germans and Life of Agricola. (Latin Translation) We have Greek tomorrow and on Monday and Tuesday we have Greek Testament and German respectively. Next term we do not have Latin or Greek, and I believe there is only one term more in which they are compulsory branches. I am not sure that there is even that. They are elective afterwards.

Mr Carpenter died quite suddenly Wednesday night of heart disease He had been sick however, since Tuesday afternoon. The funeral is tomorrow at two o clock
What have you decided about a stove. Shall I do anything about it in Utica. I think we ought to have one. If you desire I will see Mr Cross's and try to get one like that.
I am quite interested in little Eva Elizabeth. I began a letter to Hattie this evening your letter came with the news. but did not finish it; I intend to write her however. Give my love to her if you write and my sincere good wishes for the baby. and my love to Lizzie and the children as well as to Uncle Butler
I hope to hear from home before I start to know whether you have a stove or not
With Love
Eddie

Remsen, N.Y.
July 15, 1889.
My Dear Father and Aunts: -
"Procrastination is the thief of time"; "Time is money" Ergo, I have suffered myself to be robbed of an enormous amount of sordid wealth during the course of my lifetime. But it is more to the point just now to say that procrastination has delayed my writing to you for, I think it must be, about a month. and to tender my heartfelt regret for such remissness. However, I did write briefly, once, but you did not see the letter I fear, for Aunt Anna found it  among a pile of letters some two or three weeks after it was written

and it is around yet. I will not send it now, however, as it was simply to inform you of my leaving New York, written hastily on the day I started.
I did not tell you anything about my last two weeks in my Sunday work. When the Seminary closed, I did not have much to do and had to stay a month to complete my engagement at the Girls School. Well I taught in the Colonel Sunday School during that time, & did some calling, for new scholars. The superintendent desired me to stay three Sundays after the close of the Lenox Ave work, which would keep me in the city between two and three weeks longer. He spoke to Dr Terry, the pastor of the Church, who said that I might stay and that I should be paid for it.

So I took a room in East 39th St. and devoted myself to new visiting. I succeeded in getting about 25 new scholars in two weeks. I got thirty-five dollars for my work. It was really two weeks work and three Sundays.
A few days before starting home, I had an offer of a church in Buffalo, N.Y. for the summer. It was for a minister who is spending his summer in Europe. The compensation was fifteen dollars a week with use of the parsonage library, and room in the parsonage. But I had promised Aunt Anna to be home the greater part of the summer, and so refused it, promising to go in August if it should be necessary; but it seems now very likely that I shall not be needed, as the man who

went there likes it & may stay as long as anyone is needed.
I suppose I shall board with Hattie and Holden next year. Hattie's health is not very strong, but if she is strong enough, that is the understanding.
I boxed up Aunt Mary's books, or rather tied them strongly with ropes for they were boxed and had Mr. Winston's men to take them to the Freight Depot.
Seth Jones is upon a vacation You know he has been in New York for three years or so. He has changed so one would hardly recognize the same person in him. He is a very nice appearing fellow now.
As all the rest of the people here are writing, I will content myself with a single sheet, though I intended to write a long letter when I did get at it. So good bye now - Affectionately J.E.E.

P.S. to J.E.E.S's letter: -
My text of last night I will tell you. I did not say anything about the sermon because I thought the others would speak of it. My text was in Mark 14:45. "And kissed him." Short, isn't it? The subject was Judas betrayal, which was consummated by his kiss. I felt better satisfied with it after it was all over than with any other sermon I have preached, both as to material and my freedom in delivery. I wrote it last week, finishing it Thursday, excepting two or three paragraphs which I wrote Sunday, It took twenty seven or twent-eight minutes to deliver it, so I was told.
I cut down the plum trees at the end of the garden this afternoon. It

is an improvement.
You would be surprised and pleased to see the back cellar now Though the season has been wet, the cellar is dry as you would wish it. - even near the outside door, where it was always wet. This is the result of the drain which Aunt Anna had made last Spring.
Frankie is getting to be a large girl. - and she is a nice, sweet child, too. She is going home with her Aunt Louisa to Frostburg Md. in a few weeks, to spend a year. I hope it will be a profitable as well as pleasant trip for her. She is keeping a diary this year and is writing in it now. Her teacher last year was one of my class-mates. - the salutatorian of our class, Charles Law of Rome. She will go to school in Maryland next year.

Sadan Ks. May 16, 1890
My Dear Ones All: -
I reached here a time about seven oclock this morning, after a pleasant ride. I had a good seat in a reclining chair car, and slept some. - two or three hours, I suppose.
As I stepped off the car, an elderly gentleman stepped up to me, and asked if my name was Everett. I didn't deny it. It was Mr Cadwell. He had corresponded with me. I was not sure that I had written when I would be here exactly, but thought I had. I wrote before coming from New York. There were three other gentlemen at the depot

of the presbyterian church, whom I met immediately. One of them a Mr. Davis, who took me to Mrs. Crouse's to breakfast. Mr. Crouse has a nice residence. He is in business here. I have not yet learned what it is. They seem to live very nicely. They have secured a place for me to board at the hotel. but I am to stay at Mrs. Crouse's today, and this evening the church people will "call on me socially," so I have been informed.
Sedan is a place of about 1000 inhabitants, - apparently a nice quiet little town. It is eight miles from the state line. Wauneta is about twelve miles away

Mr. Crouse informs me. 
This is a beautiful morning here. I did not rain much here yesterday. But the spring has been rather too wet on the whole the tell me.
I am writing this at the Post Office & must write to Aunt Anna. so will close. Mrs. Crouse is very nice. and insists that I must go to bed pretty soon, & have a nap, after my ride.
Affectionately
J.E. Everett

Harper, Kansas, Nov 5 1890.
My Dear Father and Aunts: -
I wonder whether you are having such nice weather as we are. It is dry and delightful most of the time. I wish Aunt Anna was down here for the Winter. There are a number of people here in this locality who have come from the East on account of lung troubles & have become much better.
The Republicans are feeling blue this morning in Harper County. The Country ticket seems to have gone for the Alliance candidates, and as they have not yet heard from other parts of the State, they are somewhat depressed. I think, however, that they have no idea that the Alliance ticket is so strong in other localities. But they are in fear that Robinson is elected. They have had a hot fight down here.
I have a wedding ceremony to perform a week from today. It will be my first. It is to be in the Church. Four Hundred

invitations have been issued.
If Father wants me to go to Kansas City with him, I think I can go almost anytime, whenever he is ready. The Elders of the Church at Harper have spoken something about holding especial meetings for two or three meetings, sometime during the Fall or Winter, & the Anthony Church has thought of it, too, If that should be, my time would be taken up during that time. but excepting this, I shall be glad to go anytime.
Have you heard anything from Robbie?
My health is very good.
Affectionately
J. Eddie -

Remsen July 30 '80
Dear Aunts:
Your letter received this evening. I have decided that I had better take your advice and not go to Kansas this summer. I think myself that it would be better for me not to go. Perhaps I can go before long that is before I get out of college.
What do you think of me being a civil engineer. To be one I suppose it would be necessary for me to take a special course. The course at Cornell I think is four
years. and I think that the course of the School of Mines at Columbia College is of the same length. I am at the Post Office so cannot write a very long letter

Osawatommie Kansas Feb. 15, 1893
My Dear Aunts: - I have not written you for several days. Father has continued about the same. We hope he is gaining on the whole but it is pretty hard to see it. He continues in bed and so far as we can see, without much change. His lung is better and he thus breathes freer. I expect to go back next week, if he does not change. We will have to get someone to take care of him, if we can. We think Lyman Bullock will come. Father thinks he would like to have him. Everything looks natural about

here. This morning we are having nice Kansas weather. Yesterday we had Kansas weather, too, but not nice. Warm and cloudy in the morning, it began to rain, and then turned cold, with a heavy wind. In the afternoon I went over to see Bullock, 4 miles east and North, riding Queen, returning through town. It was a cold ride but I felt better after it. Dr. Hays has a camera. He brought it up and took a picture of the log house the other day. I will send you one. Yours with love J E Everett

Mexico, Mar. 31, 1882
Dear Aunts;, I was very glad to receive yours of the 27 and the necktie a few days before. The tie is very pretty and suits me to a te. I got a hymnbook and sent it to the proper address when at home. I got the P.O.O. all right and put the spoons and c all right. Have you heard how Robbie is? They did not think he was coming down with the fever I believe; he thought they would move about the Second week in April. I feared I would not have time to 
copy off their prices and send them to me. I will want to know also who takes the prize at the prize contest. We have been getting up at 5 or 5:30 this week; and have taken a short walk every morning till this morning before beginning to study. We have breakfast at 7 or thereabouts and supper at about 5, Affectionately your neph John E. Everett

I keep an account of all my expenditures. 
go down to Aunt Jane's so did not go, and when I got to the village Edw. Davies was not in the office and I did not see him. I suppose I cannot go to Kansas this spring. You asked me what I thought of it. - We have this week taken in a little stock of provisions possibly enough to last nearly two weeks. We bought a bu. of potatoes @ 80 ct, 2 pounds of butter @ 32 ct, 6 1/2 pounds pork 10ct, and some lemons for lemon pie. We keep an act. of what each buy and will make things even at the end of the term and very likely once or twice before them. More

bought the first supply before I came, and I paid for the things this week. The lady we board with Mrs. May was to let More have his potatoes, but many of them froze and she is afraid she will not have any to spare. I have about $1.80 left counting a dollar I lent More this week to wait till he received some more. We bought a cord of wood a day or two after I came. It being an even $2 we each paid half. It is expected that the classes I am in will read Cicero's four orations against Cataline and in Greek about 10

chapters of Xenophon's Anabasis this term. I like Cicero very much but Anabasis not so well.There are a number of scholars that take lessons in oratory. They are taught a little time Friday evenings. I do not stay in the Academy building only when I recite; most all are allowed to study in their rooms. As I am so near the school I do not have to start till the bell rings. Are Carroll and Charlie going to speak at the closing exercises of the school. If they are what are they to speak. I wish they would

Mexico, NY Mar 27 1882
Dear Aunts; I am expecting a letter from you tonight and think it no more than fair that I should send one back in exchange. This is a very pleasant village containing many fine houses. It is rather larger than I expected to see as I did not know exactly how much space would be occupied by the 1200 people. There are five churches here I believe. Sunday morning my roommate Warren More and myself went to the Methodist Church. They have a very smart minister there and

we had a very good sermon. In the evening I went to the Presbyterian Church with Johnny. He attends there. Both places are very finely finished and furnished inside - both having pipe organs. I stayed to Sunday School in the morning. I think I will get along very nicely in my studies. Both the Latin and Greek classes are ahead of me in proficiency, but by pretty close studying I think I can keep up with them. In the latin class there are about 9 or 10 - in the Greek not so many. The Greek comes the first thing in the morning - the latin the last thing and writing the last

Each recitation occupies three quarters of an hour.  I began the writing today and think I will improve by it.  Johnny boards in a pleasant place and should think in a pleasant family.  He has a front room down stairs and the one above it up stairs.  I have a front room upstairs, in the other side of the same street but several rods West.
I like my roommate  very much.  He is very intelligent steady and pleasant.  We have first rate board - good bread and butter tomatoes ham cookies and we neither of us drink tea or coffee.  I have not got acquainted

much here yet, - with only a few of the students.  I cannot take time to write more now.
With much love
John E Everett

Mexico N.Y. April 12, 1882
Dear Aunt

              I have not much to write, but perhaps think a little will be acceptable.  This morning we had quite a snowstorm, but the sun is taking the snow off now pretty fast.  The weather has been very pleasant a good part of the time since I have been here.  Before this cold spell the grass had began to look green, & the roads were quite dry. -  The time passed very pleasantly with me, and very swiftly.  I manage to keep up with my classes pretty well, I pride myself that I do better than some of them

yet I feel that things are not quite as they should be in as much as I do not do as well as the best.  Some of the students are studying very hard this time especially those of the graduating class. There is one boy in our class that is accustomed to get up at 3 o'clock or thereabouts in the morning to study.  He goes to bed early however.  We get up from 4 to 5.30 or 6 and retire at 9. - There is to be a stereopticon entertainment here tonight on Palestine. There was a entertainment in the place, last evening also, given by Comical Brown.  I did not go last night and probably shall not go

go tonight (especially as my purse contains at present just 29c.)
The students have a prayer meeting every Tuesday afternoon at 4 o clock in the Academy. The Professors and Mrs Butler attend and the meetings are led by someone chosen by an Executive Committed - The debating Society has not met this term. The students are so busy that oratorical exercises are to be had this term except at the close.
There is a Tent of Rechobites here quite thriving should think.  No license is granted here but liquor is sold.
Hope to hear from Carroll and Charlie before

long.  What did they speak at the closing exercises of school.  I suppose Maggie was not there to read her essay.
I have nothing more to write now.
Lovingly your Nephew
John Edw Everett

Osawatomie, Kan, 
          August 28th, 1882

Dear Aunts;

               As there will be a chance to send a letter to town tomorrow I think I will be prepared to embrace this opportunity.  Father sold two head of cattle today and will go to  Osawatomie with them tomorrow and leave me to get dinner make the Johnny cake &c. We have biscuits once a day and Johnny Cake once.  When I get back I believe I can teach you a little about doing house work.  Aunt Anna asked who made our

cutting time will be at hand soon The peaches are beginning to ripen. Apples are quite cheap Father sold two or three trees the other day for 20c per bushel. It is about 70 miles to Emporia from here Aunt Anna I believe asked several questions in her letter but

pies.  Pies are a minus quantity in this household but we have so many things else that we do not need them.  In fact if we had them it would be necessary to omit some of the other good things to make room for them,  We have apple sauce, rice pudding baked apples, graham and oatmeal pudding &c, &c, &c
We have not had Indian pudding until yesterday because the old meal does not make so good pudding, but yesterday father brought in some ears from the field that were pretty hard, and I grated the corn of them with 
I cannot find the letter am afraid she will have to ask again.
Lovingly 
J E Everett

a horse radish grater.  It was a warm day and I eked out that portion of my living by the sweat of my brow.

We will probably get though haying this week.  I have done hardly anything in the hay field.  I have helped with the chores and the house work.  I do the churning and generally skim the milk.  We keep the cream home in the well also the butter and churn in a tin churn in a tub of cold water which generally has to be changed from once to three times while churning.  Father does not own a

mowing machine but has his hay cut out 50c per acre.  Most of the farmers do the same way.  Father would have one of his own but he would not have time to run it himself and it would be in the hands of who ever might be working here.  I should think mowers are in some demand now as no one that cuts fathers hay has been offered 50¢ and a team furnished if he will mow tomorrow night.  He has agreed to do it if no one else can be found.  The corn is getting hard or at least a great deal of it is I expect corn-

Don't you think it would be a good plan for father to go East for a visit while I am here.  I could take care of things a while and it would be harder for him to leave if  I were not here -  in fact I am afraid he would not like to anyway, but I think he would be more apt to leaving things in my care & go than in the care of one of his hands.  I wish you would write and invite him to do so.  It would do him good to have a visit with you as well as yourselves

Osawatomie Kan, Mar 14


My Dear Aunts

                     I have not your last letter at hand, having mislaid it, so I will not attempt to answer that one in particular.  I wrote you from Burlington, a fact which I presume you are aware of before this.  I came back Saturday getting into Osawatomie about 6pm.

I became acquainted with some of the colored company that stayed in Burlington, I hear, I found one of them to be a chatauqua, in fact three, but only one was keeping up the readings Their entertainment was good, the Tuesday after they were in Osawatomie and gave good satisfaction. I told you

that I borrowed $10 of Mr Chestnut In starting out west to collect &c. When I got back I went to pay him a part of it out of the $10 that I obtained on that bill and offered him $4, but he said that father had borrowed more of him while I was away and that I might leave it till father had more to spare. So thinking that father might need it I kept it. So I am owing Mr. C. $10 and the dentist $13. I am afraid I will not be able to make enough to come home when I had thought. I would better want to have my good looks taken before I go away. I have promised several of my pictures around here. I do not like the ones taken in Utica last summer.

I did intend to have a photographer come from Paola and take our "little log cabin" but I am afraid my purse will be too low He would come and give a dozen stereoscopic views for $5. I want to try to get the likenesses of the members of our Chautauqua Circle. The Supper that I told you we were to have did not come off till last night. We had a good time all around - had the lesson first and then the supper about $9.30
Father was invited, but he did not feel well, not well enough to go. It was held at Major Williams' residence - Uncle Eddie I reckon remembers seeing him. He is the hardware merchant of

town, and Uncle Eddie probably saw him at the Cong. Church.  a large man with full gray beard.  They put up some of the delicacies and sent them with me to father. They are old settlers and were acquainted with Mother, at least Mrs. Williams was I think also Mr. Wms. 
Have you considered any plans for next year? One reason that I would like to come home early in the spring is that we might try to make some arrangements for the future. What is Uncle Eddie's advice as to what we had better do? Have you any notion of coming to Kansas?  Kansas

University is very highly spoken of - that is I have heard it so spoken of  It is located at Lawrence about 45 miles N.W. from here in the county cornering with Miami on the N.W. (Douglass) It is a town of some 7000  I think I have heard.  I would like very well to be in Kansas on account of being near Father.
The weather has been very pleasant for two or three days. Yesterday and today it has been very warm  Shaker commenced plowing Monday afternoon (the 12th) Today we have been planting early potatoes. The roads

are dry and hard. More cold weather is expected however sometime during the spring

 When do you mean to go to New York? Do you hear from Aunt Mary often I do not nor write either How is she and how getting along? Does she contemplate moving this Spring.  Do you know Byron Litchfield's address in Cincinati? Where is Niel?  
 I must close. It is half past eight and I want to go to bed early tonight for it was one oclock when I got home last night

Affectionately
John Edw. Everett

P.S.

I think Father would feel inclined to close out his business here if he thought he could situate himself satisfactorily afterwards or in a way more comfortable than he is at present situated. I think very likely if we should come to Kansas somewhere to live he might come and live with us —possibly not immediately — but at least in time. I cannot tell but I think he might — I think he would. He is going to town this p.m and I hope he may bring a letter back from you.
 J.E.E.

Utica, N.Y. Jan 21 1884,

Dear Aunts, 

  I inquired of Comstock Bros. this evening and and found that Granulated Sugar - the best quality they would sell for 8 1/4¢ & if they had a barrel opened but they did not always have one opened & would not care to open one, Raisins — London Lyers — are 275 per box. At another place to which I was recomended by the one I saw at Comstocks' Sugar would be 8 1/2 perhaps a little less for 100 pounds. A barrel at Comstocks would be 8 1/8. There are 280 or 300 lbs. in a barrel. I have not yet

inquired about clothes. I went to Plymouth church twice Sunday. That is the Congregational Church. 

 Your aff. Nephew
  J.E. Everett

Clinton, Sept. 10, 1884
Dear Aunts: 

 I came down last evening with Mr Avery and was at his house at breakfast and dinner today. I have secured a boarding-place for a week or so at Mr. Carpenter's, next house to Mr. Avery's   I have had a very pleasant time at Mr. A's.  I went on the hill this morning and was examined very slightly in Greek - in the Anabasis and will be matriculated tomorrow I think. 
 I will write to Stereotyping Co. I suppose it will be well to send the amount of their bill.  
 Much Love   J E Everett

Clinton, NY, Sept, 30, 1884,
Dear Aunts;

 I wonder very much why I do not hear from you; I received a card from Aunt Mary, written on her way to New York, but have had nothing from home I think since I came back. I hope neither of you are sick, and cannot think that you are, because I am sure you would write if you were. 
 I think I shall like College work very much. So far I enjoy it very much. I have a recitation at 9 a.m., at 11 a.m., and one at three p.m.  Rhetoric comes four times a week, Geometry three times Zenophon's Memorabilia three times, Greek Testament once, and an exercise in English Composition, once.  Wednesday and Saturday afternoons we have no recitations.  Four days in each week namely Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday, there is a students prayer-meeting at noon, which is attended by a good number of the students and in which there is manifested a good deal of interest.  At noon on Wednesday, and Saturday there are Rhetorical exercises in the chapel. I come on with a declamation two weeks from tomorrow. 

Yours of yesterday (30) has come to hand. Very glad to get it & to know that you are pretty well.

I attend the Presbyterian Sunday School last Sunday and had a class of young ladies. There is preaching in the College Chapel every Sunday,  It is one of the requirements that the students be present. 

 I have joined a fraternity, the Delta Upsilon. They board on the club system. Last year their board amounted to about $3.25 a week  I have understood. I do not know just how soon I shall begin to board with them. One of their men have a room in College for two and I shall go in with him. I shall need some furniture. He has carpets enough I shall need a stove one, or two chairs, a bed and a lamp, and perhaps some other things. I do not know exactly what he has, as he has not returned yet on account of the sickness of his father.  Warren More, whom I roomed with in Mexico is intending to go to Utica in a few days to buy some furniture for his room, and I thought that I might go with him and get some things for my room at the same time. He is also a D.U.  But I have'nt now money to make the purchases. 
 How is Frankie getting along, and how is Louisa? I have been expecting to hear from Frankie. I hope she will write before long. I shall look for a letter from her the first of next week, Monday, as it will probably reach me then if she writes Saturday. I hope you are all well & that I may hear from you soon
 Your Loving Nephew J.E. Everett

I think I ought to have a new hat.

Clinton, N.Y. Oct. 29, 1884.
Dear Aunts:

  Yours with the P.O.O. came today and a letter and card came last evening together with a letter from Aunt Mary containing a note from Asia. Thank you for the $5  I bought another set of wrappers yesterday thinking that in that way I might have more washing done home. I suppose I shall go home Monday, going up on the evening train. 
 Today ends the first half of the term, making one=twenty=fourth of the College course — not just that I suppose as the other terms are not of exactly the same length. 
 I wrote to father the other day. I had had a letter from him some time before.
 Clinton is introducing a system of waterworks. The trenchs for the pipes are being dug by Italians. There is a gang of them here of perhaps 75 or 100. Their bosses boss them around like slaves — but I suppose that is the only way to do any thing with them. 
 I am still boarding at Mr Carpenter's. There was a meeting of citizens last evening to take measures to raise money &c to relieve the Carthage sufferers. Two hundred dollars was subscribed on the spot and committees appointed to canvas the town. A committee

There was a large fire at Carthage NY on Oct. 20. RMR

of one from each class was also appointed among the College students. I was appointed from the Freshman class. I circulated a subscription paper thro' the class today & have nineteen names each representing a dollar. All the class has not been canvassed yet. I am sorry to hear that Frankie is sick. Hope she will soon be as well as ever again.

 Last Sunday I had a class in Sunday School of little girls about 10 years old. They said they hoped I would teach them again. They were very bright and well informed on the Bible. 
 We have had little flurries of snow but nothing to last as you have. The roads must be very bad.
 With very much love
 Your nephew
 J.E. Everett

Clinton, N.Y. Oct 9, 1884.
Dear Aunts;

 I got to Utica and called at the Herald office. They looked over their accounts and found the Herald had been paid for. I enclose a receipt which he gave me. I was almost late in reaching the train. In fact it had started from the depot, but I was going to meet it & was able to get on before it got under headway. I hope that you will not find this cold weather very inconvenient. I did? not call on Cousin Mary. I paid Mr Carpenter for my board this evening.  Give my love to Frankie.
 Yours Lovingly
    J. E. Everett

Clinton, Nov, 8. 1884

Dear Aunts: 

I returned safely Wednesday evening and am again well at work. I have not paid Mr Carpenter yet. The morning after I got back there was quite a fall of snow on the ground, and I was between two minds whether I had not better get a pair of rubber boots to walk up and down the hill with, having a pair of shoes up there and down here as well; but I found that the walks were kept good all the way up and I think I shall not need them.
 One of our fellows spoke to me today saying that he wanted a roommate. The rooms he had (in conjunction with two others) accommodate three, but one of his chums is to leave, and he asked if I would not take his place. The rooms I imagine are furnished rather expensively, he said the share of each is about $40, I told him I would think of the matter. It seems to me that I am very comfortably situated now, as I am. How are you all? I enjoyed being with Frankie when I was home, very much, and think of her often.  Remember me to Louisa 

With Love J.E. Everett

Clinton, N.Y., Nov. 15, 1884.
My Dear Aunties,
How are you getting along? I hope you are able to get the full benefit of this beautiful weather. It seems almost like spring.
I have spoken to Mr Owen about a rubber coat. He has a kind for two dollars which he recommends very highly. I had an idea that good ones could not be purchased for that, but he said it would wear three years.
There are only five weeks more. There will be three weeks vacation at Christmas, I understand, There is a petition around among the students to have the time lengthened to four weeks and the spring vacation (which comes about the finish of April) shortened a week. i.e. from two weeks to one week.

In regard to going on the hill to room I believe that I would like to next term. I am inclined to think that on the whole it would be better for me.
How do you hear from Aunt Mary? I have not heard from her I think since she returned, although I have written to her once. Have you heard from Father, I have not but have written to him.
Do you have readings most every evening? Have you finished Uncle Tom's Cabin?
You might suppose that now I am in College I would have a good deal to write about; but it does not seem to be so. My work I enjoy, but it is not very eventful. One day is very much like another as far as the work is concerned, and the happenings. One thing that contributes to the general pleasantness is that all the proffessors

treat the students like men, and not like boys as is apt to be the case in school, the academies &c Some of the proffessors, as might be supposed are liked and some are not. Thus far, the Freshman class have found all their proffessors very good but we are told that before spring we will not regard so highly one or two of them, but I hope that will not prove to be the case.
I went to Utica Tuesday to hear Moody. I could hardly tell at first whether I liked him or not, but have come to the conclusion that I do. His is very different in his manner of speaking from what one would expect from a man who has had such power over audiences He is very natural in his speaking He talks just as if he were

talking face to face with anyone in common conversation. but he was very interesting and held the interest of the audience entirely. A number of the students have gone to Syracuse to hear him today.
I have an engagement to teach a class in Sunday School for two weeks and, if the regular teacher does not return for three weeks. After that Miss Avery is to be absent a Sunday & I have promised to take her class.
I expect to hear from you soon, tonight I hope
Give my love to Frankie, & to Aunt Jane & Clara when you see them.
Loveingly
JE.

Clinton, N.Y., Nov 21, 1884.
My Dear Aunties,
I have received only a card from you this week. I am glad to hear Cousin Mary is with you. I have had so little time in Utica when going thro' that it has not seemed that I could call on them, tho' the last time I passed thro' I did have two hours or more.
It snowed here night before last and there is still some snow on the ground, tho' there was not enough for sleighing at all. Have you had enough for sleighing yet.
Have you heard from Hillsdale since I was home? I hope you still intend to make a visit there. I have not heard from Aunt Mary yet. What do you hear from her? Is she well?

I suppose neither of you attended the barbecue yesterday. A good many went from here. A good many went in the afternoon and a good many more in the evening. There is a train leaving here for Utica about seven and returning, something after eleven. It is a train put on especially for accommodating those who desire to attend the winter entertainments. There was a ratification procession here a week ago this evening, but no speeches. Some of the houses were illuminated very finely.
When does Mr. Hughes begin to labor on his new charge? Have our people anyone to succeed him in view?
I stayed with Huber Tuesday night, and may possibly stay with him tonight,
I am beginning to feel that I ought to be on the hill; that is, that I ought to room at the College and board with the fellows. There is a second-hand stove belonging to one

of the boys which he will sell for seven dollars. I will have Plato Jones look at it if I can, and give his opinion as to its value. - I am afraid I will need to have some money for society matters pretty soon. I am desired to pay nine dollars by the first of next month. I have about four dollars now, - a little over that. I do not know of much other expense that will be necessary to meet this term, unless I get a pair of rubber boots, or a rubber coat.
We have begun reviewing in most all our branches preparetory to the closing examination of the term. The term closes three weeks from next Tuesday or Wednesday, It has passed very rapidly. I hope to hear from you very soon. I haven't heard from Frankie yet. Yours With Love,
J.E. Everett.
P.S. After writing the above I have written to Father. I have not heard

from him since I came from home. If you ever take a notion to come down and see me, you can have my room and I can very easily sleep with some of the fellows, Huber would be glad to accommodate me I know part of the time There is a stove on the room, and I suppose we could make arrangements with Mr Carpenter for some coal - Very Lovingly - JE.

Hamilton College
Clinton, N.Y. Nov. 29, 1884.
Dear Aunties,
Aunt Anna's letter came to hand yesterday afternoon, with the check. Thank you. - Since I wrote last the man whom the fellows had intended to have me room with has returned, and it seemed a good time for me to come on the hill to stay. The room that we have was newly finished off a year ago and is very prettily papered and the woodwork is finished of nicely That stove, for seven

dollars, I learned by inquiry was cast off because it was not a good heater. We found one for $14 which is very good. It has been used a part of two years, and cast when new $34 (according to the statement of the man I bought it of which I do not believer however.) It seems to be a very good stove. We saw another stove cheeper but it quite old, of old style, and I thought it would be apt to burn more coal than one of later date.
I think I ought to have a dresser, There is a black-walnut one for sale for about $11 quite a pretty one. They tell me here that it is better to get one of black-walnut as it will always sell well. Otherwise I can get

one for perhaps eight dollars. I will pay for the stove out of the check you sent. I ought to have written about this before, but I have been busy this week. I thought that as I was coming on the hill so soon I had better come at once and help my chum get started. We sleep together. He has bed-clothing. He is a very pleasant young fellow, and a good Christian fellow, - a junior. I think I shall like him. - I hope I have not done wrong to move before writing to you about it. It would have taken some time to get an answer.
I am glad you have had a nice visit with Cousin Mary, I shall surely call there the first opportunity

I have. There is not much over two weeks of this term remaining, Thanksgiving day our fellows had a great dinner. It occupied two hours, or more. I am still reading with Miss Avery. We are reading the Marble Faun yet, but are almost thro' with it. She has invited me there to tea this evening. Last Saturday evening Plato Jones and a Miss Scoville, Miss Avery and myself met at Miss Scoville's to study the Sunday School lesson. We meet tonight for the same purpose at Miss Avery's
As to taking young men to call on Miss A I have only taken Huber and I consulted her about it before I took him.
With lots of Love
J.E. Everett

Hamilton College
Clinton, Dec, 8, 1884.
My Dear Aunties:
I am sorry I have put off writing to you for so long. I have been expecting to hear from you. I suppose you received my letter of week before last saying that I had moved on the hill. I have not heard from you since. - The term closes next week Wednesday. I think I would like to stop a day or two in Utica, on my way home. I hope I shall hear from you soon; I am quite anxious to hear; I hope you

not sick, either of you.
I have a very pleasant chum. I think I shall like him very much.
I ought to have some money to settle up here before I leave. I am owing Mr. Carpenter $13.50, and will be owing about $10.00 for board with the boys at the end of the term., that is about for three weeks. Besides that I am owing about $12 or $13 for things for the room.
Examination begins Friday. We have five branches to be examined in and there is one each day, thus letting us out Wednesday.
I havent any else to write about in particular. There was a communion service in the College chapel Sunday evening. The students have a training class

in the Bible every Sunday afternoon at three. I had not attended them until I came on the hill but have been the last Sundays. Each class has one. Only a few attend; at least it is so of our own class. The classes have prayer-meetings Friday evenings at nine o'clock. The Y.M.C.A. has prayer-meetings at noon in the chapel Monday's Tuesday's Thursday's and Friday's.
How is Aunt Mary? I have not heard from her for a long time - not since I saw her I think. I hope you are both well. I wonder why I do not hear from you. Does Uncle Eddie expect to remain in Turin this winter. I suppose of course he does.

Do you still think of going to Hillsdale. I hope you do, & that you can.
Lovingly Your Nephew
J.E. Everett.

Hamilton College.
Clinton, N.Y. Jan. 8. 1885.
My Dear Aunties,
I failed to get the bank book of Cousin Alex yesterday afternoon. I had been at Cousin Mary's to dinner and when I got to the market Cousin Alex had gone. I will go up Saturday and see to it. At the market Cousin Henry handed me twenty-five dollars and said that Cousin A. had left it for me; I did not know what to think of it, what it was for & asked him; he said it was a present. So I was able to get down here.

I found that my chum had returned on the noon train, and had five going.
The chapel bell is ringing and I must close.
Affectionately
J.E. Everett

Utica, N.Y. Jan, 14, 1885 -
My Dear Aunts:
I have at least obtained the money from the bank. I will take the liberty of keeping out of it the five dollars which I sent home the other day, and another five. There will be a term tax to pay of five dollars tonight, and I am not sure but there will be more than that to pay, two or three dollars perhaps, but that may not be called for just yet. I am not sure about it. I came to Utica this A.M. at about 11.15 and took dinner at Cousin Mary's. She is expecting to hear from you

So am I. I have not heard from you since I returned I think. But there may be a letter for me now at Clinton. When are you expecting to come to Utica. They are all well at Cousin Mary's Fannie went to Rome today and I did not see her.
Hope you will write soon
Affectionately Yours
J. Edw. Everett
P.S. There is an opportunity of buying a Society pin that cost $28 for $10. It is a good chance. Don't you think I would better accept it?

College Hill
Clinton. Jan 27, 1885.
My Dear Aunties
Your good letter of the 26th is just at hand. I took tea at Mr. Carpenter's this evening, and after tea stopped a few minutes to see Huber. He rooms in town you know. When I got on the hill I called on Plato Jones before coming to my room. He asked me if I had got my letter. and then added when I had told him I had not, that there was two cents postage to pay on it. I said, "That's Good. I am willing to

pay two cents for a good fat letter any day."
I was glad to get the text of shorthand. After looking over the alphabet, I soon deciphered the book from which it is taken Then I saw the three oblique dots above one of the words and immediately the verse. "Wherewithall shall a young man cleanse his way? By taking heed these to according to thy word" came to my mind; only I thought the first word was how. Of course I could not make out the first word to read so I got out all the other words and at last made out the first word. I hope you will send more.
We have a reading room

under the auspices of the Y.M.C.A. There are a good number of papers taken. The Tribune, Times, Herald World, Sun, Utica papers, New York Observer S.S. Times Puck Judge Graphic Independent, Harpers Weekly, Harpers Monthly Century Atlantic, N.A. Review, and others, both papers and magazines.
You need not send Maudevills Elocution but may bring it when you come.
Aunt Annas poetry is very commendable. I have not bought that pin, because I have not had the wherewithall to buy it. We board at the

same place. The cream does not flow quite so freely this term.
My health is good, and I enjoy my life here. I am afraid I enjoy myself here better than you two do up there.
But I am not so sure that ones location affects ones happiness so much. Happiness comes from within, I guess, doesn't it? Perhaps, not entirely so either. Write soon again another fat letter.
Lovingly & Hastily Eddie

College Hill
Clinton, Jan 31, 1885.
My Dear Aunties,
This is a soiled sheet but it is the only whole one I have & the book-store is closed just now. There is a book-store in the building that my room is in which keeps the books used in the College, and stationary, but I do not think it pays to buy stationary here. It seems to me they are rather high.
I would be glad if you can find my account book and bring it to

Utica. No Matter if you do not happen across it I think I left it on the shelf by Mrs. Pritchard's door I have kept account on a piece of paper since I came back.
The dresser is of black-walnut - has a very good mirror, and three drawers. It is quite neat and pretty. almost new, and will probably sell well, when I want to dispose of it.
Are there any of the steel engravings of Grandfather and Grandmother left? If there are I wish I might have one of each down here. If you cannot conveniently carry them as they are you might cut off a part of the margins.

I send a copy of my accounts. The Quintennial which I mention is a Memorial volume commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the foundation of the society, and all the fraternity took copies.
I have not yet called on Mrs. Owens people but Huber will take me before long. - I thought I had a good deal to say when I began to write but I do not seem to have. It is most time to go to dinner, which we have you know at 5 oclock. The coasting is good now and we slide down usually. I generally

get a chance to ride with some of the fellows.
Was glad to get your letter last night. Have mislaid it - so cannot answer it as I would. Thank you for the $25.
