Hamilton College.
Clinton, Feb. 9, 1885.
My Dear Aunts,
I return in this the P.O.O. made payable to Aunt Jennie. I have acknowledged the receipt of it to Mr Jones.
I haven't anything to write about this morning. It is snowing very hard just now. I stayed with Huber Saturday night. He took me to make a call in the evening. I have not heard from Aunt Mary for some time. How is she? I suppose you hear from her. How are Uncle Eddie's family.

I shall be glad to have Aunt Anna send another installment of short-hand. I have preserved the alphabet she sent.
You proposed that I state the amount my purse contains, from time to time. I have now about twenty-five cents. I sent you a statement of my expenses so far this term the other day. You have received it, I suppose.
I am not sure but you had better send my handkerchiefs by mail, as I may run short. I have not had any washed yet.
I shall expect to hear from you soon and often. Now that we have got in the habit of writing often let's keep it up.
With love. Eddie.

College Hill
Clinton, Feb. 6. 1885.
My Dear Aunts
I will take a minute to write a little. I have written to Rev Timothy Jones.
If you have not started yet, do you think you can find the pieces like my last Turin suit. the blue suit - Do not look much; I am not sure but you know just where they are. I am glad to hear from you so often, and hope we may continue to write often. I do not seem to have

much to communicate. Except in the College hue & cry of a lack of money. I guess you begin to be afraid of hearing from me, & that you receive my letters with trembling rather than joy.
I believe the College year is half over now - that is in the number of weeks. We have had four weeks of this term, & gone over about one-half of the term's work - in another four weeks or so, we shall begin to review. Yesterday I attended a funeral in town of a graduate of '78 or '79. Prof. Hopkins preached. I had never heard him before. I am very well. How are you.
Yours Lovingly J Eddie.

Delta Upsilon House. -
Hamilton College. -
Clinton N.Y. May 14, '88.
My Dear Aunts: -
Yours of May 10 came to me this morning - Just now, was glad to hear from you again. I should think you might find it a nice change to go to Olpe for a time. The aspect of nature must be enchanting in Kansas, now. It was five years ago the second of this month that I left Osawatomie. It was beautiful there then. It is nice here now, too. Last week was warm growing weather, and everybody enjoyed it. Today it is not so charming, as it is rather

cool. Still it is pleasant. Two weeks from tomorrow we have the last regular exercise of our course. The night after the Clark Prize Oratorical contest occurs, to which I was so fortunate as to be appointed. The oratory of the occasion will not, or may not, be of the finest, as the men are chosen on the merit of the orations which they wrote for the competition. The prize, however, will be awarded largely on the merit of the speaking.
In regard to Aunt Anna

(3.
I was surprised, when I went home on hearing she had been sick, to find she had been gaining so nicely. She seemed to be very cheerful, I believe she has a good deal of confidence in the new girl Alice, and finds her companionable. She feels better, more secure, I have no doubt, now that she has the doctor attend her. I think that will be well for her, - merely the impression on her, that she is sharing the responsibility of her health

with a competent judge of disease.
I am glad you are falling in love with Kansas, I feel a sort of native affection for her myself, and am always glad to hear the state spoken well of.
I feel that it complements me to complement my fathers home, and my own birthplace.
I shall go home for a week soon after Clark Prize. I cannot go to stay till after commencement on account of "Lit" business which will hold me here - Affectionately Your Eddie

Patterson House.
F.A. Patterson, Prop.
Harper, Kansas, Oct 10 1890.
My Dear Aunts: -
I have had a little trip this week. The Larmand Presbytery was held at Burton, Harvey County, fourteen miles East of Hutchinson, and I attended. Hutchinson is 60 miles north of Harper, and is the Count seat of Reno County. It is a good sized town of I suppose five or six thousand people. I had a pleasant time and got a little acquainted with some of the ministers of this Western part of the state.
I shall probably have a horse and cart in a few weeks. I shall need them as I have a good many country members, some living out a good ways from the towns. Ponies are cheep here, they tell me, and I can get a good new two wheeled cart for 12 or 15 dollars.
I am glad the milk is going to the Creamery. That must make the work easier. Does Father talk of making Robbie an offer to come to Kansas & take the farm? Affectionately
J.E.E.

Milaw, Kansas Jan 2, 1892.
My Dear Aunts: -
Last evening I spent a little time writing to little Anna, and this morning while there no work in particular to do, I shall write you a few words.
This is Saturday, and I expect it to be a busy day. I mean to spend it out on the streets and in the stores, meeting people, & finding the people by accident whom it will be worthwhile canvassing. - I tried that on one or two days at this place before, and found it worked well. It is a kind of activity better expressed by our Western word "rustling" than by any other language I can command. To "rustle" is to find the chance, & then to use it, all the time in the alert for other chances. The good "rustler"

is the person who has the knack of finding the chances, & the capacity & energy to take advantage of them. I am not convinced that I am a good rustler. I understand that the term originated among cattle men. Out on the plains the cattle were not fed in the winter, but were compelled to run loose in sleet & snow, and in order to live must nose about under the snow for the dry grass or hay underneath. That was called rustling. So when men have to nose about under frigid circumstances for a livelihood, they call it rustling. So I am trying to rustle, and I find it quite interesting for the most part. When I find a clump more prominent than surrounding clumps, my spirits are elated with the hope

2nd sheet
that I shall find a good bunch of grass under it; and when investigation proves it to be only a drift it stirs me to hasten to another clump.
Yesterday morning furnished us the first snowstorm of the season, - a sort of New Year's gift wrapped in white. The sun broke the package, however, before night. In this sunny southern clime, the frigid rigours of Winter have less than a fair chance. This morning was pretty cold at first, but it is coming out a "pretty day" even now at nine o clock.
I called at Mr. Moffetts and got the package. Thank you, heartily. The gift is very nice, and I am greatly pleased with it. I have had nothing to keep my photographs in

and I have a good many that I consider choice. - many that could not be easily replaced it injured.
I have not taken all my things from Anthony. My books are there yet, and some clothing. I have not been there for three weeks and over, and do not see that I can easily get there for several weeks to come.
I am sorry you felt it necessary to send that 50 to Osawatomie. I wish you had kept it to make the burden of your incidental expenses lighter. How are you getting along now financially? Has anything else come in lately?
My address is still at Harpers I think I shall be in and about Milan till Tuesday or Wednesday, & likely all of next week. Affectionately J.E.E.

Merrill, Mich. June 20, 1893.
My Dear Aunts: -
We are still looking for some word from you. I should think this warm weather would be good for boat traveling. It has been 103 & 4, ° the last two of three days here. - I suppose it must be very warm in Chicago.
I am going to Wheeler today to spend the day, probably, or else I shall walk up this afternoon. The weekly prayer meeting is tonight. I have been attending it lately, and will continue to do so if I can while the weather is good.
We hope you will be on your

way to Merrill before this reaches you.
We have a prophecy of your coming in the form of some newspapers that have come addressed to you.
With love to yourselves and Cousin
I am as Ever
J.E. Everett.

Merrill, Mich Aug 9. 1894.
My Dear Aunts: -
The days slip away so stealthily that I can hardly account for them. You have been gone now two weeks. You are getting settled I suppose and are beginning to see what you want to do.
The meetings have kept us busy. - that is me, and the baby has kept Ella busy. He has been very worrysome. He has no more teeth. He grows some notwithstanding his many troubles. He is in short clothes now, and of course looks like a little man.

2.
I received a letter from Mr. Van Auken some days ago, in which he asked if I would consider a call to Centralia, Ill. After a few days of hesitation, and of vacillation I wrote to him that I would consider a call, but that I could not agree to anything until I had seen the people & given them an opportunity to see me, and that I could not leave here without giving the church ample warning, perhaps two or three months. - Yesterday heard again from him asking if he should make an appointment for the 19 for me. I replied affirmatively. So a week from next Sunday, I suppose I shall be in Centralia

3.
I have said nothing as yet to anybody here but Will. I shall have to close the church for that Sunday, probably. Centralia is a city of about 6000 people, on the Illinois Central R.R, 250 miles from Chicago. - somewhat south of the center of the state. and I think midway between the Eastern & Western boundaries.
The church is not a large one - only 65 members; but Mr. Van Auken says: "it is a fine opening for church work. and Centralia is a beautiful city." It is an opportunity which I feel like considering. I feel like courting it rather more than Litchfield, because the latter seems to

be a village which has seen its best day, while Centralia is a good sized town which has increased in population between the last two census reports. If a good church can be built up there, it would be very likely a desirable place to settle in permanently. At all events, it seems wise to look into this matter. So I am booked for a good little journey next week. Centralia I find in 1890 had a population of 4700. Mr. Miller our evangelist, who is from Ill. & who has worked in Centralia in revival work, says it is a growing place, and that there is good chance for a thriving & successful church.
Our meetings will close

Friday evening. Sunday I hope we may take a few members into our church. Will write you if we do.
Mary Sweeny came home this week. There is another week of her school, but she will remain at home. She reports a very good school. 
What would you think about going to Centralia, in case it should seem expedient for us to go there. Mr. Miller says it is in the midst of a fruit country, and a very pretty town. Of course I shall inquire as to expense of living & c. 
Mrs. Hudson has not returned, though the Doctor is expecting her every day.
If I put Cooley's Constitutional Law on that list, you need not

search for it, because I find it here. The baby is cross & I am "minding" him. So I will close. Ella says you must excuse her this time, because baby has taken so much of her time. Mrs. Cerby was here yesterday washing and ironing, but did not finish the ironing and Ella is trying to get through with it. She sends love with mine
Your Nephew
J.E. Everett

Merrill, Mich., Oct 31 1894
My Dear Aunts: —

I have heard nothing from you since Saturday evening, but we hope no news is good news in this case. We know you have not much time nor strength to write, and so we will try not to expect to hear, too, often. We think you ought to have more help than you had when you wrote last.
 We received a letter from Hattie this morning. I had written her of Aunt Mary's illness. We have a very urgent invitation to visit there at Thanksgiving. We do not know whether we can do so, or not. 
 We are to have a "gentlemen's tea," tomorrow evening to take the place of a Ladies Aid. The gentlemen are providing the refreshment, will wait on the tables, wash the dishes, &c, &c. We expect to have a good jolly time, and hope to have a good crowd as well. Mr. King is going to move from Breckenridge. Next Sunday will be his last. He does not know yet where ye will go. I have had very little talk with him: — simply met him on the train last evening.

It has been rainy since Monday evening. This morning is inclined to be pleasant. The roads are muddy. They were very good before the rain. We took a long ride Monday, taking Katie & her mother too. 
  With Love,
   J.E. Everett.

P.S. Do you have any idea what you will do with that type in pages. (the Addysydd)? Will you keep it for future use, in case it may be needed? Keep it in the pages, set up?  I think I will ask Frank to get that other box that I had intended to take, boxed up, and have him ship it to me.   I think of getting up a small church sheet occasionally, setting it myself, and printing it on Whitney's press. I think there will be type enough for the solid matter in that box, and I can get a little type for headings &c.  I am not sure about it yet, but am pondering over it.

 J.E.E.

Google Translate chokes on "Addysydd" but my little dictionary says "addysg" = "learning, knowledge, education, instruction" so it is something along those lines. RMR

Merrill, Mich
Nov. 3, 1894.
My Dear Aunts: -
We were much relieved to hear that Aunt Mary is getting better. We trust she will gain steadily now.
Our "gentlemen's tea" passed off nicely. Among our waiters were Misters Gould, Hunt Perkins, Hudson Cunningham, Burnham, Delong, Smith, and White. We held it in the store Mr. Stevens used to have his flowers in. We realized something over seven dollars.
We put up our coal stove yesterday. It took pretty much all day to black it clean the nickel, mica, & get the pipes fitted

But it is very comfortable now.
It is quite cold this morning.
Have you heard how Mary Everett is? Roberts is pretty well now. He was very good yesterday, But some days he is very worrisome
It is Saturday & I will be pretty busy today. So I will close.
With Love from all to all
In Haste
"JE."

Merrill, Mich Nov 21 1894.
My Dear Aunts: — 

 I am afraid I cannot write much of a letter, with Roberts on my lap; but I will try to write a few words. He is pretty well now; but he has not got beyond giving us a good deal of trouble. He is eight months old; and growing. He shows his teeth very prettily when he laughs. He can navigate around the room quite well in his tender, and on the whole is improving very much.
 We are talking of going up to your rooms today to see if everything is in order there. If you decide not to come back the Fall it would be well for us to try to dispose of your coal, would it not?  I presume we will be able to sell it.  I have not heard of anyone who would want it, but it is very probable we will will find some who have not enough to last them through the winter.   Have you decided positively whether you will stay or come?  We still hope you may see your way to come. 
 The gentlemen of the Church & Congregation are preparing to have a Thanksgiving Dinner.  We will be obliged to go at it in earnest from this time on

I am trying to give up my Wheeler appointment.  I went to Alma Monday to see if a student could be found who could and would like to take the field. I found one whom the Wheeler people will like I think. He was highly recommended by the President. I had spoken nothing about the matter tot he Wheeler people up to that time. That afternoon I sent my resignation, recommending at the same time the young man.

 Ella got a nice new couch the other day. It is very pretty.  We have the books all in the dining room.  We had the large bookcase cut off at the bottom about eight or nine inches, so that it would go in the S.E. corner of the dining-room where the old couch was. We have placed it there across the corner between the two windows. The small bookcase we have put just West of the dining room window on the South side of the room. It makes the room look very nice. Then the new couch we have put in the parlor where the small bookcase used to be. The old couch we have consigned to the shed, hoping to dispose of it to some one. It is pretty poor in the upholstering and will not be useful till it is repaired. We are not getting any new carpets. We have put glass in the pantry cupboard doors

  Yours of 19 just received

3

and painted the pantry, intending to paper it this week or next.  Our girl is not so useful as we hope she would be. She was the greatest part of Monday and Tuesday washing, and did not even then get through.   

 There are a number of new babies in town. Among their mamas are Mrs. Frank Thomas and Mrs. Ed Perkins. ("Little Mrs. P") 
 I had a wedding last Monday evening. I was not acquainted with the parties. They came to the house.
Aunt Mary's S.S. class have hung together thus far, but they feel somewhat discouraged about it sometimes. Eliah said Sunday to Ella that they would probably go into my class if they had not promised you they would hang together till your return
 Baby can patty-cake in his own way. But he is cross, all the same and gives his mother little rest. 
 I have written quite a long letter. But Roberts went to his mother or I would have had to stop long ago.
 With love from us all
  JE Everett
We have been up to the rooms and found every thing all right, so far as we could see.  The coal seems unmolested, and also every thing in the house.

Merrill, Mich Dec 5, 1894.
My Dear Aunts: ——

 I have given up Wheeler at last. Perhaps I wrote you of it in my last. I found a young student at Alma who would like to take the place; and recommended him. I presume he was with them last Sunday. We do not know what to do with old Fan. whether to keep her all Winter or not. After Mr. Burnham's kindness, we hesitate to return her in the middle of the Winter
  We did well on the Thanksgiving dinner and Supper, clearing nearly thirty dollars. The gentlemen took hold and work splendidly. There was an abundance of provisions contributed, for both dinner and supper. These were turkeys, chickens a good, chicken pies, roast beef, boiled ham, potatoes, squash, pies, cakes fried cakes, pickles cheese, celery &c &c. Everybody seemed to enjoy it.
 Tomorrow we expect Supt Warren to visit us. We have called a meeting for two oclock in the afternoon and

after that I shall take him to Breckenridge where he speaks in the evening.

 Mrs. Massecar has been confined to the house for a great deal of the Fall. She was out for the first time at our Thanksgiving dinner. They are very good friends to us, and the Church.  Eliah and Grace are faithful as ever.
 Chicken-pox is prevailing here. Little Roberts came down with it last Friday. He is recovering, but his face is anything but attractive. The other children are well.
 Perhaps Ella will add a word.
  J.E.E.

Kiowa, Kan. Dec. 28, 1894.

My Dear Aunts. 

 I think so many times of writing to you but I am so busy all the time and not a very good correspondent. I have not been a bit well for about two months now and with our family of seven I have more than I can do. It seems almost impossible to have each one do their share of picking up &c. Lewis does not seem to have the least idea of picking up after himself of of order in the home. shirts and socks are left where he steps out of them and of course if Lewis is allowed to do it Howard thinks it hard on him to insist on his

doing so and so, if the older one does not do it, I shall be glad when Lewis stay is over for I am far from being able to wait on him of course J.E. thinks I must have patience and I certainly try to do so but nevertheless it is a great burden to me. J.E. is enjoying his vacation of two weeks from his school work and I am sure he needed it. I think J.E. is more lighthearted this year than I have ever known him to be and I presume it is because he is making a little more and of course is not so hampered financially but he is working very very hard. Mollie is staying with me this week and will very likely stay next week and as she needs the money will be more apt to stay. We all enjoyed your Christmas token which we received that

day. I am very thankful indeed for the Ladies Home Journal for I enjoy it very much. J.E. has ordered the Advance sent to your address. One of the Ladies of the Church gave me a dainty little piece of china which I prize very much.

Roberts is growing all the time and is very fat. JE and I had him with us riding the other day and the seat being rather narrow he kept slipping down his papa said to him that he did not have any square corners that he was so round he could not help sliding down but papa why did you not have some square corners put on? why did you not tell God when he made me and then I would not slip down all the time.  The little fellow was very much interested in Santa Claus this year. My father is in Canada spending his Christmas

taking Douglass with him. Lottie is staying with Maggie out in the Country where she is teaching. The Ladies of the Church are getting ready for their Annual experience social which takes place next week. J.E. received one of father Adair photos a few weeks ago I presume he told you at the time. Well it is time to go to the kitchen and see about dinner. J.E is up town Howard and Roberts are out playing. Zaidee is with Mollie in the kitchen. Lewis is up close to the coal stove in the dining room where we have a little stove. I will send one of our local papers with a little notice of school in.  Write soon, I will try and write more frequent in the future. Yours with lots of love

Ella Everett

Merrill  Mich., Mar 4, 1895
My Dear Aunts: —

 We are sorry Aunt Anna is so poorly now. We hope she will be getting better now. But the weather does not seem to show much sign of warming up. We had good Spring weather for a time but yesterday it became Wintery again. I am afraid you have had a bad Winter in New York. 
 We are glad if you like the picture. We think it is nice. It is very natural too. He is improving all the time. He can walk a little. but is very

slow in striking out for himself  He has not let go and started out of his own accord till yesterday.  His bowels continue to give him trouble. We are giving him Cascara now.

 We have made no arrangements about leaving here in the Spring. We think it likely we will not take the initiative in leaving; and so most likely we will remain another year.
 Our little Juvenile Missionary Society which we started a few months ago is doing nicely. They are preparing to have a social in three weeks - A Penny Social it will be.  There will be

slow in striking out for himself  He has not let go and started out of his own accord till yesterday.  His bowels continue to give him trouble. We are giving him Cascara now.

 We have made no arrangements about leaving here in the Spring. We think it likely we will not take the initiative in leaving; and so most likely we will remain another year.
 Our little Juvenile Missionary Society which we started a few months ago is doing nicely. They are preparing to have a social in three weeks - A Penny Social it will be.  There will be

slips of paper with questions on them which are to be answered by a penny e.g. Where on the penny is youth and old age. (the date, as 1894) Where is a "sign of royalty" (the crown on the figures head) where a house of worship (the temple) symbol of Victory (the laurel) mode of punishment. (stipes) A weapon (bow and arrow) Devoted young man (bow) A messenger (one cent.)  Portion of a hill (brow) An animal (hair)  One way of expressing matrimony (United)  A flower (two lips) 

 The next Ladies Aid will be given by Misses Chennel, Hodgkin Knick and Lane.  Miss Lane is a

teacher who teaches a mile west of the villege and boards with Mrs. White. She is Mrs. White's cousin. The Aid will be given in the church this week Thursday.

 The village election is to be held next week. We are trying again to elect members on the council who will be in favor of law and order.
 Give our love to Aunt Jane.
 We enclose a ticket for our penny social. The children will sell them. If a person buys one and does not come, we will be one cent ahead anyway
 With love J.E. Everett.

Merrill, Mich., March 18, 1895.
My Dear Aunts: -
Roberts was one year old yesterday. He walks around very independently, going wherever he sees fit in the house. He likes to get into the pantry and open the doors to the shelves, and get at the pans and other things there. He is very busy and active and of course gets pretty tired.
The Spring is opening gradually. The nights are cold, and the days mild There is but little snow.
Last Friday evening we had a lecture in our church on Pluck Patience and Push. It was under the auspices of the Men's Club. The speaker was Dr. Hunting a Presbyterian minister of Flint, who was formerly President of the Alma College. It was a thoroughly good

address, inspiring as well as entertaining. The people appeared to be very well pleased. The speaker charged ten dollars and expenses. We came out sixty cents ahead. We did not expect to make much of anything. It was the lecture we wanted, and also to demonstrate that this place is capable of patronizing such a thing successfully. Some, even members of the club, were opposed to having it. But others of us think it will not be the last thing of the kind.
We are agitating very actively the building of a Church parlor and thinking we may be able to get it started this Spring.
Tonight there is a stereopticon entertainment, in the church given by a Rev. Frank Hoyt under the auspices of the Maccabee Tent.

3)
We have not heard from Father since the first of March. I wrote to him last week, the day I wrote to you last. I am eager to hear from him now after he has got the farm on his hands again.
Tuesday A.M. Mar 19. - We attended the entertainment. It was fairly good, and much enjoyed, I think by most of the audience.
Ella wants to know when we may look for you back in Merrill, and I do too. It is lonesome here without you. There is a family in your old rooms. We do not know how long they will stay, We do not know either what prospect there will be of getting rooms or a small house, but hope there will be opportunities. There is a house we think of now that will be vacant. Whether it is spoken for or not we do not know, It is the house Frank Thomas has been living in He has bought a house and will be

moving after awhile. The house he leaves belongs to Mr. Forsythe, and is the second house this side of the church. - a little green house, - you may remember it. We think the rent is about five dollars.
We are pretty well except Ella. She is just able to be around and not much more. How is Aunt Anna. Does she recover well from her recent attack? Are you still alone? We have a girl a new one who came yesterday, a Mary Adamack. She seems to take hold well.
With love
From Your Nephew
J.E. Everett.

Merrill, Mich., Mar 25, 1895.
My Dear Aunts: -
I received a letter from Father this morning; and judge that he is not getting along very well. I am intending now to go to see him next week. - I think I shall start next Monday, a week from today. We have been talking the matter over this morning, and trying to plan so that Ella could go too. But we fear it will seem best for her not to go this time, I think I will take Howard along,
I have neglected saying anything about that watch. I would like to have it now that I am going away. I do not think you can get it here in time, But possible you may. I want you to take no extra trouble about it, and I want you to be sure it will make no especial difference if I do not get it. I have

travelled many times before without a time piece. Our jeweler here says the watch can be packed easily in a box large enough so that quite a good of paper can be put around it, and that the only thing to be done besides packing it snugly is to take a very small of slip of paper, double it, so that it forms a weak spring, and place it under the balance wheel, - under one side of the balance wheel - so that it will keep the wheel from moving. Do not put yourselves to inconvenience. I think it entirely improbably that you can get it here in time; and if you do not it will not make much difference to me. Indeed, in traveling, probably Howard would care more for the watch than I.
I do not know that this trip will be of any avail, but I feel that I ought to take it, and hope that

by seeing how things are going on I may be able to help Father to get along better. I wish we might dispose of things there and that Father might come back with me. But I feel that such a thing is almost out of the question.
We are as well as usual.
With love from all
Your Nephew
J.E. Everett.

Merrill, Mich., May 15, 1895.
My Dear Aunts: -
I enclose Post Office Order for twenty dollars. ($20.) I think that was the amount for the coal, was it not?
We are still at Merrill, without anything decided, We are hopeful however, and think we will settle somewhere in this state. We will not go to Standish; I think I told you that, did I not? We hope we may be able to go to the Southern part of the state, but we are not possessed of any opportunities in that quarter as yet.
It is quite cold here. It froze hard last night night. I presume you have had this cold wave as well as we. Yesterday morning the ground was white with snow. Which did not

melt away till towards evening.
How are you getting along with garden & c. You wrote that you intended putting one in, I believe? We have had our garden patch plowed, and a few, though not all the potatoes in. The cold wave and snow came on me before I had it all planted, and I guess it is just as well.
We have had two or three letters from Hattie lately. They seem well. Holden received thirty-five members into their church recently.
We wish we could drop in and call on you; or that you could come in and give us a call. Perhaps we may meet again before Winter
With love from all
Your Nephew
J.E. Everett
P.S. I observe the order is made to Mary E Everett. You will need to think of this, I suppose, in having it cashed & sign accordingly

Merrill, Mich., May 23, 1895.
My Dear Aunts,
I wrote you a card last night telling you of father's misfortune. I send you herein Robert's letter.
We have decided to pack up and go to Kansas. We will probably look for a church there. We will go about next Wednesday or Thursday. We are starting on something of an uncertainty, because we do not know where Ella and the children will stay, whether at Robert's or whether they will go to Uncle Edward's. I will write to both this morning, making inquiries.
J.E.E.
We very likely will not go till about Friday or Saturday In that case we will stay in Chicago over Sunday

Merrill, Mich., May 24, 1895.
My Dear Aunts: -
We feel that it will not be wise to leave your things here, unless it be for but a very short time. While we are here it is all right, but it will be different when we are gone, we are afraid. We had not troubled ourselves about it at all, as long as we thought we would settle somewhere in Michigan. We thought we would ship them right along with our things, and keep them till you should decide where you would want them. But it seems different when we think of going so far. We do not know what to do with them. Still if it seems best, we may leave them here, for a little time.
We think of starting the latter part

of next week and staying in Chicago over Sunday, providing we receive word from Cousin that it will be convenient to her for us to do so.
We hope you will not worry about us going to Kansas. It seems almost a providential arrangement. We are looking for a field. We are not tied here longer. We have had our thoughts on Kansas more or less: and now it becomes really necessary for me to go for a time. Considering all things, it appears as though our path is plainly marked out for us that way. We hope it will prove for the best. Perhaps you will turn your faces that way too, when we get settled.
We have been thinking that little Roberts is just about the age that I was when I was taken to Steuben, though I suppose I was not quite so old when I left Kansas, though I do not know when Mother started East.
I had begun to repair the buggy,

3
I had taken the top off, and also the box. The floor was poor, so I put a part of it in new, so that it is good and durable in that respect. I was preparing to paint it. I had begun sand papering it. I am at a loss to know what to do with it now. There will not be time for me to finish it. But I will decided in a day or two what disposition to make of it. I thought with a little repairing & the painting, it would be a very good buggy. But it would need two or three coats, & there is not time now to finish it. I had an appointment to preach at Kendall Mich. for a week from next Sunday, but I have written to cancel it.
We will of course hear from you before we leave. Don't think too much about our moving. Things are being shaped for the best, we may be sure of that. With love from us all
Your Nephew J.E. Everett.
(Over)

P.S. Night before last, we were invited eleven miles into the country to marry a couple. Yesterday afternoon we were to be there. We drove down and had a very pleasant time. Found good Christian people, and enjoyed our trip very much. We have returned Old Fan, but have a standing invitation to go for her any time. We use Mr Burnhams buggy too, so it is wonderfully nice, They are very good friends to us.
We are invited to Mrs. Whites for tea tonight. Mrs. Mason's tomorrow night and Mrs. Bulkley's Monday night
With Love
J.E. Everett.

Merrill, Mich., May 29, 1895.
My Dear Aunts: -
We are in the midst of packing. We hope we will get nearly through today, though we are afraid we will be rushed up to the last minute. This is Wednesday. Tomorrow we hope to have time & get the goods shipped without having to wait till late in the day. Then Friday we expect to start, - going to Chicago for Sunday & starting from there Monday evening.
We will send you perhaps a very few things, and perhaps you would prefer to have us take everything with us. Ella's father is here crating stoves today. Yesterday he crated the buggy.
I have been trying to

persuade Ella to go to Steuben & stay with you for the Summer - her and Zaidee and baby, but she thinks she would worry and that she would rather prefer to keep the family together, so I presume she will come with me unless we get definite word for Kansas, which shall change our minds. We have not heard a second time.
With great haste,
and love
J.E. Everett

Osawatomie Ks. June 10, 1895,
My Dear Aunts: -
We have neglected writing you since coming to Osawatomie, having been a good deal upset. Our goods of course are lagging on behind. Tuesday afternoon at about one o'clock we reached Osawatomie. (June 4.) Robert met us at the depot and took us to his house, which is small, and not suited to accommodate a large company. We we royally entertained however until the next day. We had it in our minds before coming that if we could secure furnished rooms in Osawatomie to wait until our goods should come it would be agreeable to us. So after dinner, the day we came

Robert took me to town and we engaged in house hunting, and finally found two rooms on the ground floor, in which the landlady agreed to put a little furniture. We have found them convenient in many ways, but they are not more than half furnished, and do not give us much room. There is a gasoline stove which we have had but it was not till yesterday that we could get it to work.
Ella has been sick ever since we came to Kansas. - yes and before. In Chicago, where we spent from Saturday night to Monday afternoon, she was unable to go out much, and at Roberts she was worse rather than better, Thursday morning we

If he would be contented to dispose of his dairy & reuthrs? farm for what it would bring, and then live with us, it would be much better; so we think, and so others think. - some others at least with whom I have talked. But he is not disposed to do so. We will therefore probably go to the farm & try it for a while.
I am however making inquiries about churches. Perhaps if we go to the farm, we can find a church which I can supply within easy distance, and at the same time live at the farm. Perhaps if we could get an invitation from a church, father might change his mind.

I have not said anything to Father about the matter you wrote me of to Chicago. He has been so worn out, that we have not talked very much about plans & c, though we have some. He feels strongly about remaining on the farm, I think. He thinks he will get stronger, and very probably he will, but there is too a good deal of doubt about it. I have told him that I think it would be much wiser not to go in debt anymore, but to raise the necessary money by disposing of some of his stock but he cannot see it so.

surprised to see him looking so badly when we came, but he was rapidly recovering by that time. When we first saw him, his forehead and the right side of his face were covered with a thick almost continuous scab. His right ear along the outer edge was deeply scarred, his lips, the under one particularly was raw, (apparently so, at least,) and the upper part of the back of his head, and the back part of the top of his head was in one thick, continuous scab, in which there was some matter. He has improved much since then in his appearance. The scalp is about the same, but the sab has come from his face a great deal. His hands were also scabbed some

3,
called Dr. Pace, and he pronounced the difficulty tonsilitis (if that is the way to spell it.) Yesterday we had the doctor here again, and he thinks the swelling will break today, and if not, then we will lance it. She has suffered a great deal. The baby has been well till yesterday when he got quite feverish and fretful; and last night he did not rest well, being very worrisome. Today he appears better.
Father is quite feeble. He was very badly burned, and it seems strange that he recovered from it. So at least, they seem to think who saw him from the first. We were

5
when we came, but they are much better, and it would seem, almost well now.
The burn must have been something of a shock to his system. He is weak, tires easily, is sleeply a great deal of the time, - and yet he does not sleep nights very well. He can hardly tell whether he is improving from day to day. - though I think he is. He seems stronger on the whole than when we came. We have taken no measures towards building as yet. My time has been pretty well taken up with what little house work & c we have. I drive to the farm every day, too, for milk, potatoes, eggs & c. keeping the team here.
We are rooming South of the

opera house block, three blocks on the corner corresponding to the Opera house block. Our landlady is Mrs. Bruner, The house is a three storied one. I mention these things thinking Aunt Mary may recognize the name or the place.
I am sorry I have not written before, but being pretty tired myself and having my hands full, I have put it off from day to day.
We hope to hear from you soon
With love - Your Nephew
J.E. Everett.

At all events, I do not feel inclined to constrain him. We came West on his account and are disposed to yield something in order to comply with his wishes.
J.E.E.

Osawatomie, June 11, '95
My dear sisters,
That beautiful blanket came in due time, but I was not able to write and thank you for it as I now do. it is very acceptable and useful. The pin cushion was just what I needed, and the silk handkerchief I shall value because it was father's. I wrote you about a week ago. I stopped writing without finishing, because I was utterly weary. I lost all my glasses with everything else in the fire. The only one thing I saved was the separator. I am living with John Eddy in two furnished rooms in Osawatomie His goods have not come. Ella has been sick ever since she has been home with quinsy The doctor lanced it yesterday, but it is still very painful. Eddy goes to the farm every morning for milk eggs and potatoes. The boys feed the new milk to the hogs. I am left prostrated as if I had had a spell of sickness.

If you send me any bedding send by Express. The freight is too slow. We keep a team down here. Will you be able to lend me any money? I want four hundred dollars. It would be safe on the farm. The lumber I could get on cash. I am not able to do any thing now, but I hope to soon. Cousin Mary Ann sent me a very nice blanket. Eddie talks of staying with me.
Father wants me to finish this and say that he is too tired to write any more. He tires easily. I cannot tell whether he is gaining in strength but think perhaps he is some. The weather is good for crops. There was a

good rain night before last, and another this morning. Ella does not seem to gain as yet. Yesterday the doctor lanced her throat, but it did no good so far as we could see. The baby is well. Was feverish and fretful Sunday afternoon and through the night, but was better yesterday, and appears well today. We hope you are well. It seems as though we ought to go on the farm Father feels as though he could not be contented anywhere
else, and it is hardly safe for him to be alone. With love Your Nephew J. E. Everett

Osawatomie Ks June 19 '95
My Dear Aunts,
I did not tell father about the matter you wrote me of in Chicago till the day before yesterday. Thought to have told him when he wrote that letter to you after I came, asking if you could make the loan. But at that time Ella was quite sick. Father himself was very feeble and downcast, and I hardly had the heart to tell him, We were in rooms which were practically for one; and the neighbors were just across the hall. There was nothing like retirement, Before we left Robert's

Father was so unlike himself that I could not talk much to him, or at least I was very uninclined to do so. He has seemed better the last few days. Though he seems better he is far from strong. He feels it himself. - indeed he feels it, it appears, more than I had supposed he did until yesterday. He told me yesterday that he feared he would not regain his strength all summer, and said that he wished I could go on with the farm this summer in my own way, as he did not seem to be able to think or plan. that he felt his weakness in that way. The goods we shipped from

Merrill were not prepaid. Durkee said they need not be. I had intended to prepay it until that morning. - the morning we started, In taking the goods to the depot, ours were placed in a car, and those that went to Remsen were placed in the depot. Durkee had to make a list of everything of course. We did not get the things over until late the day before we started, so that Durkee was a good deal hurried. When I went to the depot the morning we came away, we found that he had not made a list of the Remsen things and could not tell me what the cost would

be. As he said the freight could be paid at the other end, I thought I would let him do it that way though he offerd to try & list the things before the train came   In Chicago I made arrangements with Cousin M.A.R. for her to send you the $20 which you had sent. I found I needed to borrow a little & she kindly consented to lend it and as she did not have much on hand she was to send you that $20 in a few days.  I hope you have received it by this time. We did not dispose of Aunt Anna's Loan & Building share. We do not intend to dispose of our shares, but keep up the payment of them from here. We will send our books to Mr Mason

5.

and let him receipt them, each month, leaving them with him or we will send enough to pay for 3, 6, or 12 months in advance & then he could return the book.   I am writing in haste. We are getting settled, which has been slow work, on account of Ella's health. 

 With love, 
  J.E. Everett.

Father's idea of appealing to the Utica Cousins is his own. I had known nothing of it till he gave me his letter to read & finish. Ella says she will write you before long

Smith Center, Kansas
September 18,1909,
My Dear Aunt Mary
I will write just a word this morning to let you know that we are getting along as usual. We are having some hot weather yet,  but with cool days interspersed and pleasant lights for sleeping; so that on the whole the weather is very comfortable. Today is, thus far, nice and cool and is now after ten in the morning.
On Tuesday of this week, we went to Athol, a town 8 miles West of us, to visit our Congregational minister and family there, Mr Read, Helen & Mary and I went, going on the train at 10 or 11 o clock & returning at six.
The
